results.title: Topsy-turvy = Topsy turvy
results.creator_credit: Thin Man Films, Greenlight Fund, Newmarket Capital Group, Simon Channing-Williams and Mike Leigh
results.brief_description: Known best for his realist depictions of contemporary working class English lives, “Topsy-turvy” finds Mike Leigh exploring the nineteenth century world of the London stage. The successful operatic team of Gilbert and Sullivan find that they have had their first flop after two decades of successful collaboration. Sullivan, the team’s composer (played by Allan Corduner), blames the stale storylines of Gilbert (Jim Broadbent). It is not until Gilbert visits an exhibition of Japanese culture that he finds inspiration again. This leads him to the creation of the story of “The Mikado”, one of the duo’s most successful productions. Though “Topsy-turvy” offers a fascinating biography of Gilbert and Sullivan - one that does not shy away from examining Sullivan’s obsession with brothels and intoxication, or Gilbert’s childlike relationship with his wife - it also offers an intriguing glimpse into the everyday lives of actors, technicians and stagehands of a previous century. The cinematography and art direction in this film are of a consistently high standard, bringing the claustrophobic, garish world of nineteenth century London vividly to life. The film won Academy Awards for make-up and for costume design. It is a musical and visual feast.

results.title: Topaz [DVD]
results.brief_description: A French operative named Devereaux (Frederick Stafford) is hired by a CIA agent to travel to Cuba and investigate rumours of Russian missiles and a NATO spy group known as ‘Topaz’. They suspect there’s a traitor in the entourage of President De Gaulle. It seems that Devereaux is onto something when the investigation leads to worried governments, murder, betrayal and suicide. As he heads home to expose a double agent, his life is endangered by forces who want to keep the truth hidden. Cast includes: John Forsythe, Philippe Noiret and Dany Robin, John Vernon and Karin Dor. Screenplay by Samuel Taylor based on the novel by Leon Uris. Music composed and conducted by Maurice Jarre.

results.title: Top gun
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Don Simpson, Jerry Bruckheimer and Tony Scott
results.brief_description: Directed by Tony Scott, “Top gun” was the film that catapulted Tom Cruise into mega stardom. Cruise plays Lieutenant Pete ‘Maverick’ Mitchell, a hotshot navy pilot, with no respect for rules, regulations or authority. Maverick is training at the Top Gun Naval Flying School, where he is out to prove himself to be the best of the best, at all costs. Maverick flies recklessly, but with skill, co-piloted by his best mate Nick ‘Goose’ Bradshaw (Anthony Edwards). Maverick is somewhat haunted by his father’s legacy, also a pilot, whose error whilst flying may have caused his own death and that of others. At the school Maverick encounters competition to be the top pilot from Lieutenant Tom ‘Iceman’ Kazanski (Val Kilmer) who mocks Maverick’s braggadocio and family history. Simultaneously Maverick is attracted to an instructor at the school, Charlie (Kelly McGillis) and is forced to face his personal demons in light of the strengthening feelings for her. “Top gun” features several daredevil flying scenes and has a sub-plot involving a run-in (mid-air) with some rogue Russian pilots. “Top gun” was the highest grossing film of 1986 in the United States. Also starring Tom Skerritt, as a flight instructor, and Meg Ryan as the Goose’s wife.

results.title: Tom Jones
results.creator_credit: Woodfall Film Productions and Tony Richardson
results.brief_description: Tom Jones (Albert Finney) is found as a newborn in a wealthy squires bed. The illegitimate child grows into a man attractive to all women who happen to pass him in 18th century rural England. Throughout this comic soap opera of love, family and Bruegelesque debauchery, Tom Jones is certainly put through a lot before the lengthy and irreverent film’s conclusion. The plot follows Tom as he is kicked out of home and travels to London, pursued by the woman he loves. There are plenty of adventures along the way, including much feasting, heaving of breasts, sword fighting and a masked ball, just to name a few. The truth of Jones’ parentage is always in question, he doesn’t even know who his real parents are. None of the hardships faced during Tom’s adventure bother him and it’s not often that the smile leaves his attractive face. Based on the classic novel by Henry Fielding, this precursor to ‘Alvin Purple’ is both satirical and bawdy.

results.title: Tom Brown's School Days
results.brief_description: In this marvellous Hollywood version of British public school life, Tom Brown finds life at Rugby brutal, but eventually helps to become a civilising influence for his schoolmates. Immediately on arrival at Rugby, Tom is befriended by a character named East and together they begin the age old battle against the schoolyard bully. This classic novel is a story of courage, survival of the initiation ritual, and the struggle for acceptance.

results.title: Tokyo story = Tokyo monogatari
results.brief_description: Ozu considered what many regard as his finest film to be about the disintegration of the Japanese family system. Ordinary family events - the visit of parents to see the children and their cool reception - are profoundly moving as Ozu portrays them. ‘Tokyo Story’ is actually a recasting of Leo McCarey’s ‘Make Way For Tomorrow’ which his collaborator, Noda, had seen but Ozu had not. As in most of his later films there is a pervasive nostalgia, a sense of loss. Although a loosely plotted leisurely survey of the extended family structured around journeys, the film is full of conflicts triggered by the grandparents’ visit in which characterisation both enriches and qualifies stark thematic oppositions.

results.title: Tokyo Joe
results.creator_credit: Santana Pictures, Robert Lord and Stuart Heisler
results.brief_description: Joe Barrett (Humphery Bogart) returns to Japan after World War II in the hope of piecing his life back together. Joe was told his wife, Trina (Florence Marly), died during her internment in Japan. However, on arrival he learns that she is alive and married to lawyer Mark Landis (Alexander Knox) and that the child they are raising could be his. Joe, still in love with Trina vows to get her back. In order to stay in Japan, he applies for an airline franchise. He is introduced to Baron Kimura (Sessue Hayakawa) who agrees to assist with the application in return for a partnership in the business. Soon, Kimura is blackmailing Joe into smuggling war criminal back into Japan, otherwise he will reveal that Trina participated in anti-American broadcasts on Japanese radio during the war. Produced by Bogart’s company, Santana Pictures, ‘Tokyo Joe’ was the first film to be granted permission by the Army authorities to be shot in US-occupied Japan. This production marks the return of actor Sessue Hayakawa to the American screen after a 20 year interruption.

results.title: To Sir, with love
results.brief_description: A novice teacher faces a class of rowdy, undisciplined, working-class punks in this classic film that reflected some of the problems and fears of teens in the sixties. Sidney Poitier gives one of his first performances as Thackeray, an unemployed engineer who turns to teaching in London’s tough East End. The graduating class, led by Denham (Christian Roberts), Pamela (Judy Geeson), and Barbara (Lulu who also sings the hit title song), sets out to destroy Thackeray as they did his predecessor by breaking his spirit. But Thackeray meets the challenge by treating the students as young adults who will soon enter a world where they must stand or fall on their own. When offered an engineering job, Thackeray must decide whether he wants to stay. From the novel by E. R. Braithwaite.

results.title: To Live and die in L.A.
results.creator_credit: New Century, SLM, Irving H. Levin and William Friedkin
results.brief_description: This action packed movie centres around two LA cops, one who eventually gets killed in the line of duty and the other who seeks his partner’s revenge. Stars William L. Petersen, Willem Dafoe, John Pankow, Debra Feuer, John Turturro, Dean Stockwell and Robert Downey Snr. Based on the novel by Gerald Petievich.

results.title: To Kill a mockingbird [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Pakula-Mulligan Productions, Brentwood, Alan Pakula and Robert Mulligan
results.brief_description: This is an atmospheric adaptation by Horton Foote of Harper Lee’s sensitive novel of the same name. Told in retrospect, it successfully tackles the themes of racial prejudice in America’s Deep South with the gradual maturing of compassion and social insight in children. Gregory Peck plays Atticus Finch, the soft spoken, small town, Alabama lawyer given the responsibility of defending Tom Robinson, a black man unjustly accused of rape. This is perfectly balanced with Finch as the family man who has the added responsibility of bringing up two motherless and inquisitive children, played by Mary Badham and Phillip Afford. (Awards: Winner of three Academy Awards, including Best Actor for Gregory Peck)
